docs.abstract: At a time of grave investor uncertainty over the coronavirus, economists warned that the president could throw fuel on the fire.
docs.snippet: At a time of grave investor uncertainty over the coronavirus, economists warned that the president could throw fuel on the fire.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Saturday that he had the power to remove or demote Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, renewing a long-running threat against the central bank’s leader at a time when it could further roil volatile markets.

headline.main: Trump Says He Could Demote Fed Chair Powell, Risking More Market Turmoil

docs.abstract: President Trump’s investments in stocks and bonds are holding up no better than the S&P 500.
docs.snippet: President Trump’s investments in stocks and bonds are holding up no better than the S&P 500.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump, the first self-proclaimed billionaire to occupy the White House, has long asserted that he is one of the world’s best businessmen and investors.

headline.main: Trump Is Losing Money in the Markets, Too
headline.print_headline: Trump Apparently Is Losing Money in the Markets, Too

docs.abstract: The $2 trillion aid package is expected to save jobs and bail out companies, but it reorders the relationship between government and private industry.
docs.snippet: The $2 trillion aid package is expected to save jobs and bail out companies, but it reorders the relationship between government and private industry.
docs.lead_paragraph: The $2 trillion coronavirus rescue package that the Senate passed on Wednesday will fundamentally transform the U.S. government by placing thousands of businesses and millions of workers on federally funded life support.

headline.main: The Coronavirus Economy: When Washington Takes Over Business
headline.print_headline: What Happens When Washington Holds the Levers of Capitalism

byline.original: By Jim Tankersley, Alan Rappeport, David Gelles, Peter Eavis and David Yaffe-Bellany

docs.abstract: Unemployment claims are about to dwarf anything seen before.
docs.snippet: Unemployment claims are about to dwarf anything seen before.
docs.lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

docs.abstract: Businesses are grappling with how to deal with a potential outbreak. Here’s what they’re doing, and how it could affect their workers.
docs.snippet: Businesses are grappling with how to deal with a potential outbreak. Here’s what they’re doing, and how it could affect their workers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Furloughs. Sick leave. Working from home.

headline.main: Working From Home: How Coronavirus Could Affect the Workplace
headline.print_headline: Advice on Coronavirus and the Workplace

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

docs.abstract: A health care worker in New Jersey created a digital venue for people in the field to chronicle poor working conditions that may put patients at risk. “It is disgusting,” one nurse wrote.
docs.snippet: A health care worker in New Jersey created a digital venue for people in the field to chronicle poor working conditions that may put patients at risk. “It is disgusting,” one nurse wrote.
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 1,200 health care workers have used a private online document to share their stories of fighting the coronavirus pandemic on the front lines.

headline.main: Nurses Share Coronavirus Stories Anonymously in an Online Document
headline.print_headline: A Private Forum Where Nurses Share Their Fears

docs.abstract: The central bank takes Treasury Department loan guarantees and uses them to stand up huge programs. Here’s how that works.
docs.snippet: The central bank takes Treasury Department loan guarantees and uses them to stand up huge programs. Here’s how that works.
docs.lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has a favorite talking point: With the Federal Reserve’s help, the government will turn a $500 billion spending package working its way through Congress into a $4 trillion booster shot for the United States economy.

headline.main: How the Fed’s Magic Money Machine Will Turn $454 Billion Into $4 Trillion
headline.print_headline: Poof! How the Fed Will Turn $454 Billion Into $4 Trillion

docs.abstract: With overrun hospitals facing an acute shortage of masks, people are pulling out their sewing machines to fill the void.
docs.snippet: With overrun hospitals facing an acute shortage of masks, people are pulling out their sewing machines to fill the void.
docs.lead_paragraph: They are scrounging for fabric, cutting it up, stitching it together. They are repurposing drapes, dresses, bra straps, shower curtains, even coffee filters. They are building supply chains, organizing workers, managing distribution networks.

headline.main: A Sewing Army, Making Masks for America
headline.print_headline: A Crafty Army Mobilizes to Sew Masks for America

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

byline.original: By David Enrich, Rachel Abrams and Steven Kurutz

docs.abstract: While public health experts warn people to take precautions, these popular media figures insist that the virus is overhyped.
docs.snippet: While public health experts warn people to take precautions, these popular media figures insist that the virus is overhyped.
docs.lead_paragraph: Misinformation about the coronavirus continues to circulate across swaths of the American media — on popular podcasts, in blog posts, in online videos and on prime-time cable news shows — as recently as this week.

headline.main: From Jerry Falwell Jr. to Dr. Drew: 5 Coronavirus Doubters

docs.abstract: Welcome to On Tech, a daily newsletter on how technology is changing all of our lives — for better or worse.
docs.snippet: Welcome to On Tech, a daily newsletter on how technology is changing all of our lives — for better or worse.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome! The pandemic has turned everything we know upside down, and we are relying on technology more than ever to work, go to school, stay informed, entertain ourselves and stay connected to people we love.

headline.main: Why a Pandemic Is Bringing Out Our Best Online
